items.question: Overall prognosis for recovery from this episode

answers.text: Good/Fair: partial to full recovery is expected
Poor: little or no recovery is expected and/or further decline is imminent

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Rehabilitative prognosis

answers.text: Good: marked improvement in functional status is expected
Guarded: minimal improvement in functional status is expected, decline is possible

answers.text: Life expectancy is 6 months or fewer
Life expectancy is greater than 6 months

items.question: Frequency of primary caregiver assistance

answers.text: One to two times per week
Several times during day and night
Three or more times per week

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Type of primary caregiver assistance

answers.text: ADL assistance (e.g., bathing, dressing, toileting, bowel/bladder, eating/feeding)
Advocates or facilitates patient's participation in appropriate medical care
Financial agent, power of attorney, or conservator of finance
Health care agent, conservator of person, or medical power of attorney
IADL assistance (e.g., meds, meals, housekeeping, laundry, phone, shopping, finances)

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Sensory status: vision

answers.text: Normal vision: sees adequately in most situations, can see medication labels, newsprint.
Partially impaired: cannot see medication labels/newsprint, but CAN see obstacles in path, and surrounding layout, can count fingers at arm's length.
Severely impaired: cannot locate objects without hearing or touching them OR patient nonresponsive.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Sensory status: hearing and ability to understand spoken language

answers.text: Has moderate difficulty hearing and understanding simple, one-step instructions and brief conversation, needs frequent prompting or assistance.
Has severe difficulty hearing and understanding simple greetings and short comments. Requires mult repetitions, restatements, demonstrations, addtl time.
No observable impairment. Able to hear and understand complex or detailed instructions and extended or abstract conversation.
UNABLE to hear and understand familiar words or common expressions consistently, OR patient nonresponsive.
W/ min difficulty, able to hear and understand most multi-step instructns and ordinary conversatn. May need occasional repetition, xtra time or louder voice.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Sensory status: speech and oral expression of language

answers.text: Expresses complex ideas, feelings, and needs clearly, completely, and easily in all situations with no observable impairment.
Has severe difficulty expressing basic ideas or needs and requires max assistance or guessing by listener. Speech limited to single words or short phrases.
Min diff in xpressing ideas/needs (may take xtra time, occasional errors in word choice/grammar/speech intelligibility, needs min prompting or assist).
Patient nonresponsive or unable to speak.
UNABLE to xpress basic needs even w/maximal prompting or assist but is not comatose/unresponsive (e.g., speech is nonsensical/unintelligible).
Xpresses simple ideas/needs w/moderate diff (needs prompting or assist, errors in word choice, org. or speech intell). Speaks in phrases/short sentcs.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.

items.question: When short of breath

answers.text: Never, patient is not short of breath
When walking more than 20 feet, climbing stairs
With minimal exertion (e.g., while eating, talking, or performing other ADLs) or with agitation
With moderate exertion (e.g., while dressing, using commode or bedpan, walking distances less than 20 feet)

answers.text: No incontinence or catheter (includes anuria or ostomy for urinary drainage)
Patient requires a urinary catheter (i.e., external, indwelling, intermittent, suprapubic)

items.question: Bowel incontinence frequency

answers.label: NA
answers.text: Patient has ostomy for bowel elimination
Very rarely or never has bowel incontinence

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Does this patient have an ostomy for bowel elimination that (within the last 14 days): a) was related to an inpatient facility stay, or b) necessitated a change in medical or treatment regimen?

answers.text: Patient does NOT have an ostomy for bowel elimination.
Patient's ostomy was NOT related to an inpatient stay and did NOT necessitate change in medical or treatment regimen.
The ostomy WAS related to an inpatient stay or DID necessitate change in medical or treatment regimen.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Cognitive functioning

answers.text: Alert/oriented, able to focus and shift attention, comprehends and recalls task directions independently.
Requires assistance/direction in specific situations (e.g., all tasks involving shifting of attention) or consistently requires low stimulus environmnt due to distractibility.
Requires considerable assist in routine situations. Is not alert and oriented or is unable to shift attention and recall directions more than half the time.
Requires prompting (cueing, repetition, reminders) only under stressful or unfamiliar conditions.
Totally dependent due to disturbances such as constant disorientation, coma, persistent vegetative state, or delirium.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: When confused

answers.text: During the day and evening, but not constantly
In new or complex situations only
On awakening or at night only

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: When anxious

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Depressive feelings

answers.text: None of the above feelings observed or reported
Sense of failure or self reproach

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Behaviors demonstrated at least once a week

answers.text: Disruptive, infantile, or socially inappropriate behavior (EXCLUDES verbal actions)
Impaired decision-making: failure to perform usual ADLs or IADLs, inability to appropriately stop activities, jeopardizes safety through actions
Memory deficit: failure to recognize familiar persons/places, inability to recall events of past 24 hours, significant memory loss so that supervision required
None of the above behaviors demonstrated
Physical aggression: aggressive/combative to self/others (e.g., hits self, throws objects, punches, dangerous maneuvers w/wheelchair or other objects)
Verbal disruption: yelling, threatening, excessive profanity, sexual references, etc.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: grooming

answers.text: Able to groom self unaided, with or without the use of assistive devices or adapted methods.
Grooming utensils must be placed within reach before able to complete grooming activities.
Patient depends entirely upon someone else for grooming needs.
Someone must assist the patient to groom self.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Current ability: grooming

answers.text: Able to groom self unaided, with or without the use of assistive devices or adapted methods.
Grooming utensils must be placed within reach before able to complete grooming activities.
Patient depends entirely upon someone else for grooming needs.
Someone must assist the patient to groom self.

items.question: Ability to dress upper body

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: dress upper body

answers.text: Able to dress upper body without assistance if clothing is laid out or handed to the patient.
Able to get clothes out of closets and drawers, put them on and remove them from the upper body without assistance.
Patient depends entirely upon another person to dress the upper body.
Someone must help the patient put on upper body clothing.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Current ability: dress upper body

answers.text: Able to dress upper body without assistance if clothing is laid out or handed to the patient.
Able to get clothes out of closets and drawers, put them on and remove them from the upper body without assistance.
Patient depends entirely upon another person to dress the upper body.
Someone must help the patient put on upper body clothing.

items.question: Ability to dress lower body

items.question: Prior: dress lower body

answers.text: Able to dress lower body without assistance if clothing and shoes are laid out or handed to the patient.
Able to obtain, put on, and remove clothing and shoes without assistance.
Patient depends entirely upon another person to dress lower body.
Someone must help the patient put on undergarments, slacks, socks or nylons, and shoes.

items.question: Current ability: dress lower body

answers.text: Able to dress lower body without assistance if clothing and shoes are laid out or handed to the patient.
Able to obtain, put on, and remove clothing and shoes without assistance.
Patient depends entirely upon another person to dress lower body.
Someone must help the patient put on undergarments, slacks, socks or nylons, and shoes.

items.question: Bathing ability

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: bathing

answers.text: Able to bathe self in SHOWER OR TUB independently.
Aid: a) for intermittent supervision/encouragement/reminders, OR b) to get in/out of shower/tub, OR c) for washing difficult to reach areas.
Participates in bathing self in shower or tub, BUT requires presence of another person throughout the bath for assistance or supervision.
Unable to effectively participate in bathing and is totally bathed by another person.
UNABLE to use the shower or tub and is bathed in BED OR BEDSIDE CHAIR.
With the use of devices, is able to bathe self in shower or tub independently.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Current ability: bathing

answers.text: Able to bathe self in SHOWER OR TUB independently.
Aid: a) for intermittent supervision/encouragement/reminders, OR b) to get in/out of shower/tub, OR c) for washing difficult to reach areas.
Participates in bathing self in shower or tub, BUT requires presence of another person throughout the bath for assistance or supervision.
Unable to effectively participate in bathing and is totally bathed by another person.
UNABLE to use the shower or tub and is bathed in BED OR BEDSIDE CHAIR.
With the use of devices, is able to bathe self in shower or tub independently.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Toileting

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: toileting

answers.text: Able to get to and from the toilet independently with or without a device.
UNABLE to get to and from the toilet but is able to use a bedside commode (with or without assistance).
UNABLE to get to and from the toilet or bedside commode but is able to use a bedpan/urinal independently.
When reminded, assisted, or supervised by another person, able to get to and from the toilet.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Current ability: toileting

answers.text: Able to get to and from the toilet independently with or without a device.
UNABLE to get to and from the toilet but is able to use a bedside commode (with or without assistance).
UNABLE to get to and from the toilet or bedside commode but is able to use a bedpan/urinal independently.
When reminded, assisted, or supervised by another person, able to get to and from the toilet.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Transferring

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: transferring

answers.text: Bedfast, unable to transfer and is UNABLE to turn and position self.
Bedfast, unable to transfer but is able to turn and position self in bed.
Transfers with minimal human assistance or with use of an assistive device.
Unable to transfer self and is UNABLE to bear weight or pivot when transferred by another person.
UNABLE to transfer self but is able to bear weight and pivot during the transfer process.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Current ability: transferring

answers.text: Bedfast, unable to transfer and is UNABLE to turn and position self.
Bedfast, unable to transfer but is able to turn and position self in bed.
Transfers with minimal human assistance or with use of an assistive device.
Unable to transfer self and is UNABLE to bear weight or pivot when transferred by another person.
UNABLE to transfer self but is able to bear weight and pivot during the transfer process.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Locomotion

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: ambulation

answers.text: Able to independently walk on even/uneven surfaces and climb stairs with or without railings (i.e., needs no human assist or assist device).
Able to walk only with the supervision or assistance of another person at all times.
Bedfast, unable to ambulate or be up in a chair.
Chairfast, unable to ambulate and is UNABLE to wheel self.
Chairfast, UNABLE to ambulate but is able to wheel self independently.
Requires device (e.g., cane, walker) to walk alone OR requires human supervision/assistance to negotiate stairs/steps/uneven surfaces.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Current ability: ambulation

answers.text: Able to independently walk on even/uneven surfaces and climb stairs with or without railings (i.e., needs no human assist or assist device).
Able to walk only with the supervision or assistance of another person at all times.
Bedfast, unable to ambulate or be up in a chair.
Chairfast, unable to ambulate and is UNABLE to wheel self.
Chairfast, UNABLE to ambulate but is able to wheel self independently.
Requires device (e.g., cane, walker) to walk alone OR requires human supervision/assistance to negotiate stairs/steps/uneven surfaces.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Feeding or eating

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: feeding

answers.text: Able to feed self independently but requires: a) meal set-up OR b) intermittent aid/supervision OR c) liquid/pureed/ground meat diet.
Able to take in nutrients orally AND receives supplemental nutrients through a nasogastric tube or gastrostomy.
UNABLE to feed self and must be assisted or supervised throughout the meal/SCTack.
UNABLE to take in nutrients orally and is fed nutrients through a nasogastric tube or gastrostomy.
Unable to take in nutrients orally or by tube feeding.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Current ability: feeding

answers.text: Able to feed self independently but requires: a) meal set-up OR b) intermittent aid/supervision OR c) liquid/pureed/ground meat diet.
Able to take in nutrients orally AND receives supplemental nutrients through a nasogastric tube or gastrostomy.
UNABLE to feed self and must be assisted or supervised throughout the meal/SCTack.
UNABLE to take in nutrients orally and is fed nutrients through a nasogastric tube or gastrostomy.
Unable to take in nutrients orally or by tube feeding.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Planning & preparing light meals

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: prepare light meals

answers.text: a) Able to indep plan and prep all lt meals for self or reheat delivered meals OR b) Physically/cognitively/mentally able to prepare lt meals.
Unable to prepare any light meals or reheat any delivered meals.
UNABLE to prepare light meals on a regular basis due to physical, cognitive, or mental limitations.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Current ability: prepare light meals

answers.text: a) Able to indep plan and prep all lt meals for self or reheat delivered meals OR b) Physically/cognitively/mentally able to prepare lt meals.
Unable to prepare any light meals or reheat any delivered meals.
UNABLE to prepare light meals on a regular basis due to physical, cognitive, or mental limitations.

items.question: Transportation

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: transportation

answers.text: Able to independently drive a regular or adapted car, OR uses a regular or handicap-accessible public bus.
Able to ride in car only when driven by another person OR able to use bus/handicap van only when assisted/accompanied by another person.
UNABLE to ride in a car, taxi, bus, or van, and requires transportation by ambulance.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Current ability: transportation

answers.text: Able to independently drive a regular or adapted car, OR uses a regular or handicap-accessible public bus.
Able to ride in car only when driven by another person OR able to use bus/handicap van only when assisted/accompanied by another person.
UNABLE to ride in a car, taxi, bus, or van, and requires transportation by ambulance.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Laundry

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: laundry

answers.text: a) Able to independently take care of all laundry tasks OR b) Physically, cognitively, and mentally able to do laundry and access facilities.
Able to do only light laundry, (minor hand wash or light loads). Due to physical/cognitive/mental limitations, needs assist with heavy laundry.
UNABLE to do any laundry due to physical limitation or needs continual supervision and assistance due to cognitive or mental limitation.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Current ability: laundry

answers.text: a) Able to independently take care of all laundry tasks OR b) Physically, cognitively, and mentally able to do laundry and access facilities.
Able to do only light laundry, (minor hand wash or light loads). Due to physical/cognitive/mental limitations, needs assist with heavy laundry.
UNABLE to do any laundry due to physical limitation or needs continual supervision and assistance due to cognitive or mental limitation.

items.question: Housekeeping

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: housekeeping

answers.text: a) Able to independently perform all housekeeping tasks OR b) Physically, cognitively, and mentally able to perform all housekeeping tasks .
Able to perform housekeeping tasks with intermittent assistance or supervision from another person.
Able to perform only LIGHT housekeeping (e.g., dusting, wiping kitchen counters) tasks independently.
UNABLE to consistently perform any housekeeping tasks unless assisted by another person throughout the process.
Unable to effectively participate in any housekeeping tasks.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Current ability: housekeeping

answers.text: a) Able to independently perform all housekeeping tasks OR b) Physically, cognitively, and mentally able to perform all housekeeping tasks .
Able to perform housekeeping tasks with intermittent assistance or supervision from another person.
Able to perform only LIGHT housekeeping (e.g., dusting, wiping kitchen counters) tasks independently.
UNABLE to consistently perform any housekeeping tasks unless assisted by another person throughout the process.
Unable to effectively participate in any housekeeping tasks.

items.question: Shopping

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: shopping

answers.text: a) Able to plan for shopping needs and indep perform shopping tasks OR b) Physically/cognitively/mentally able to take care of shopping
Needs some assistance: a) By self is able to do only light shopping and carry small packages OR b) UNABLE to go shopping alone
Needs someone to do all shopping and errands.
UNABLE to go shopping, but is able to identify items needed, place orders, and arrange home delivery.

answers.text: a) Able to plan for shopping needs and indep perform shopping tasks OR b) Physically/cognitively/mentally able to take care of shopping
Needs some assistance: a) By self is able to do only light shopping and carry small packages OR b) UNABLE to go shopping alone

items.question: Ability to use telephone

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: telephone use

answers.text: Able to answer the telephone and carry on a normal conversation but has difficulty with placing calls.
Able to answer the telephone only some of the time or is able to carry on only a limited conversation.
Able to dial numbers and answer calls appropriately and as desired.
Able to use a specially adapted telephone (i.e., large numbers on the dial, teletype phone for the deaf) and call essential numbers.

answers.label: NA
answers.text: Patient does not have a telephone.
Totally unable to use the telephone.
UNABLE to answer the telephone at all but can listen if assisted with equipment.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.

items.question: Management of oral medications

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Prior: management of oral medications

answers.text: Able to independently take the correct oral medication(s) and proper dosage(s) at the correct times.
Able to take medication(s) at correct times if: a) indiv dosages prep in advance OR b) given daily reminders OR c) uses drug diary or chart.
UNABLE to take medication unless administered by someone else.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.

answers.text: Able to independently take the correct oral medication(s) and proper dosage(s) at the correct times.

UNABLE to take medication unless administered by someone else.

items.question: Management of inhalant &or mist medications

items.question: Prior: management of inhalant medications

answers.text: Able to independently take the correct medication and proper dosage at the correct times.
Able to take medication at the correct times if: a) indiv dosages are prep in advance by another person OR b) given daily reminders.
UNABLE to take medication unless administered by someone else.

UNABLE to take injectable medications unless administered by someone else.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Management of equipment

answers.text: If someone else sets up equipment (i.e. fills portable oxygen tank, provides patient w/prep solns), patient able to manage all other aspects of equipment.

answers.label: NA
answers.text: No equipment of this type used in care.
Patient is completely dependent on someone else to manage all equipment.
Patient is only able to monitor equipment (e.g., liter flow, fluid in bag) and must call someone else to manage the equipment.
Patient manages all tasks related to equipment completely independently.
Patient requires considerable assistance from another person to manage equipment, but independently completes portions of the task.

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Management of equipment

answers.text: Caregiver is completely dependent on someone else to manage all equipment.
Caregiver is only able to complete small portions of task (e.g., administer nebulizer treatment, clean/store/dispose of equipment or supplies).
Caregiver manages all tasks related to equipment completely independently.
Caregiver requires considerable assistance from another person to manage equipment, but independently completes significant portions of task.
If someone else sets up equipment, caregiver is able to manage all other aspects.

items.question: Therapy need

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Emergent care

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Emergent care reason

answers.text: Cardiac problems (e.g., fluid overload, exacerbation of CHF, chest pain)
Improper medication administration, medication side effects, toxicity, anaphylaxis
Injury caused by fall or accident at home
Respiratory problems (e.g., shortness of breath, respiratory infection, tracheobronchial obstruction)
Wound infection, deteriorating wound status, new lesion/ulcer

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: To which Inpatient Facility has the patient been admitted?

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Discharge disposition

answers.text: Patient remained in the community (not in hospital, nursing home, or rehab facility)
Patient transferred to a noninstitutional hospice
Unknown because patient moved to a geographic location not served by this agency

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Discharge support services or assistance

answers.text: Yes, assistance or services provided by family or friends
Yes, assistance or services provided by other community resources (e.g., meals-on-wheels, home health, homemaker assistnc, transportation assistnc)

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Acute care hospitalization reason

answers.text: Hospitalization for ELECTIVE (scheduled more than 24 hours before admission) care
Hospitalization for URGENT (scheduled within 24 hours of admisson) care

items.copyrightNotice: Copyright © 2002 Center for Health Services Research, UCHSC, Denver, CO. Used with permission.
items.question: Reason for hospitalization

answers.text: Exacerbation of CHF, fluid overload, heart failure
Improper medication administration, medication side effects, toxicity, anaphylaxis
Injury caused by fall or accident at home
Wound or tube site infection, deteriorating wound status, new lesion/ulcer
